newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS- JULY 24.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS- JULY 24.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek financial press:

-- Social dialogue between government, unions and employers' representatives appears to be at a standstill two months before it is scheduled to end. According to Wednesday's meeting, the points of divergence appear to be the reduction of non-wage costs and restrictions on paid employment amongst pensioners as well as the expansion of part-time employment.
--Fuel prices are pressuring inflation anew, with state-run DEP on Wednesday announcing a new increase, the third in a month, following the strong showing of the dollar on international markets.

--Conservative opposition New Democracy has called for immediate measures to make structural adjustments to the Greek economy, following ND leader Costas Karamanlis's meeting with the governor of the central bank.

--The unfettered appreciation of the dollar on international markets broke a new record against the drachma on Wednesday, rising five drachmas at fixing to close at 285,420 drachmas. The dollar's rise has serious repercussions on the external debt as well as the balance of payments.

--The Athens Chamber of Commerce and Industry (EVEA) has developed a six-point plan in its half-yearly report to improve competitiveness in the economy which includes "bold" structural initiatives. The plan proposes a drastic reduction in public spending, indexation of the tax scale, with simultaneous wage restraint, deregulation of the market and stepping up privatisation, reform of public administration, educational reform and transforming the social insurance system into a capital return system.

--After two months of depressing news, inflation looks to fall again in July, according to the latest forecasts from the national economy ministry. The minstry is reported to say that inflation will fall by 0.1 percent to 5.4 percent and will continue to fall until to September to reach 5.0 percent.
--Money markets remain edgy with interest rates resisting despite steady support of fluidity by the Bank of Greece.

--Government and employers have proposed wage increases at the level of projected inflation for 1998 with unions pushing for higher increases. National Economy and Finance Minister Yannos Papandoniou stressed the need to safeguard real incomes for workers without endangering the government's goal of reducing inflation to 3.0 percent by the end of 1998.
--President of the Republic Kostis Stephanopoulos has urged every Greek to contribute to the effort to reach national targets in the economic sector.
--Attika Enterprises has posted an increase of 50.89 percent in profits before tax, according to its half-yearly report. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
